729478f.title: Richmond: Richmond Terrace - Tysen Street
729478f.text:
Richmond Terrace, south side, between Tysen Street and Kissell Avenue, showing a broad view of the Sailors' Snug Harbor.
E. T. Clegg  about 188O's After 1898
729478f.folder: Richmond Terrace & Tysen Street, Staten Island, NY

729459f-a.title: Richmond: Richmond Terrace - Tysen Street
729459f-a.text:
Richmond Terrace, south side, between Tysen Street and Kissel Avenue, showing Sailors' Snug Harbor, seen from the Kill Van Kull. On the left is the Randall Memorial Church in the style of the late Italian Renaissance. To its right is the Music Hall. The building on the right, with the low dome, is the Main Building, used for administrative purposes. Sailors' Snug Harbor, a home for retired seaman, was founded in 1801 by the will of Captain Robert Richard Randall, son of a privateer, who bequeathed the bulk of his fortune for the establishment and support of an institution for destitute sailors. The site was purchased in 1831 and the asylum was opened in 1833. The Harbor contains more than fifty buildings.
About 1900
Photo by August Loeffler
From P.L. Sperr Collection
729459f-a.folder: Richmond Terrace & Tysen Street, Staten Island, NY

729477f-b.title: Richmond: Richmond Terrace - Tysen Street
729477f-b.text:
806 Richmmond Terrace, adjoining the S.E. corner of Tysen Street, showing the "Stone Jug" built about 1770 by Captain John Neville. This was at one time the home of Judge Jacob Tysen. See also 'Legands.,Stories and Folklore of O1d Staten Island by Hines and Davis, p. 30.
1924
P. L. Sperr
(2)
The same, at a later date. It appears in Bromley's
1917 Atlas as the Knickerbocker Hotel.
July 7, 1932
P. L. Sperr
(3)
An additional view seen from the opposite direction.
July 7, 1932
P. L. Sperr

729462f-b.title: Richmond: Richmond Terrace - Tysen Street
729462f-b.text:
Richmond Terrace, south side, between Tysen Street and Eissel Avenue. Shown are two buildings and a summer playhouse of the Home for Sailors' Orphans, part of Sailors' Snug Harbor. The orphans' home is located on the east side of Kissel Avenue, slightly north of Castleton Avenue. The buildings were later
demolished.
View 1: October 21, 1925
View 2: January, 1927
View 3: June 30, 1927
P. L. Sperr
729462f-b.folder: Richmond Terrace & Tysen Street, Staten Island, NY

729461f-a.title: Richmond: Richmond Terrace - Tysen Street
729461f-a.text:
Richmond Terrace, south side, between Tysen Street and Kissel Avenue. The three views show the ruins of the Home for Sailors' Orphans, within, the grounds of Sailors' Snug Harbor. The actual location of the Home was on the east side of Kissel Avenue, about 175 yards north of Castleton Avenue, at the south end of the Harbor grounds. Kissel Avenue can be seen in views 2 and 3; in the background of view 1 appears the Harbor hospital.
June 30, 1927
Views 1, 2, 3
P. L. Sperr
729461f-a.folder: Richmond Terrace & Tysen Street, Staten Island, NY

729460f-b.title: Richmond: Richmond Terrace - Tysen Street
729460f-b.text:
Richmond Terrace, south side, between Tysen Street and Kissel Avenue. Shown are views of the corn field and creek on the grounds of Sailors' Snug Harbor. In the background are the stacks of the Edison electric plant, on Richmond Terrace
and Bard Avenue.
View 1: 1937
Views 2,3: 1938
P. L. Sperr
729460f-b.folder: Richmond Terrace & Tysen Street, Staten Island, NY

729463f-a.title: Richmond: Richmond Terrace - Tysen Street
729463f-a.text:
Richmond Terrace, south side, between Tysen Street and Kissel Avenue. Shown is the Main Building of Sailors' Snug Harbor, the home for destitue seamen. The Harbor was founded in 1801 by the will of Captain Robert Richard Randall and the asylum was opened in August, 1933. It occupies many acres of
land and contains over fifty buildings.
About 1905
By Mulford Simonson
From Staten Island Museum Collection through P. L. Sperr
(2)
The hospital of Sailors' Snug Harbor, seen from
Henderson Avenue.
May 28, 1926
P. L. Sperr
729463f-a.folder: Richmond Terrace & Tysen Street, Staten Island, NY
